results.title: La Spagnola
results.creator_credit: Steve Jacobs, Anna-Maria Monticelli, Wild Strawberries, SBS Independent and Australian Film Commission
results.brief_description: Directed by Steve Jacobs and set in 1960, “La Spagnola” is one family’s story of the migrant experience in Australia. Lola (Lola Marceli) is a beautiful, tempestuous Spanish woman living in a remote industrial town with her boorish husband, Ricardo (Simon Palomares), and their teenage daughter, Lucia (Alice Ansara). When Ricardo decides to leave her for his Australian mistress, Lola is left destitute and pregnant turns violent and vengeful. Her daughter, sensitive, lonely, mocked at school, and confused by her mother’s anger toward her, seeks refuge in an aunt and tries to reconcile with her absent father. Lola is driven by a quest for revenge against the two who have robbed her of her only security in a strange land. Lola and Lucia, each striking out hatefully at the other, are on a collision course, plotting their separate plans for vengeance. Also starring Alex Dimitriades as a local playboy, romantically interested in both mother and daughter. Mostly in Spanish, with Italian and English, and with English subtitles.

results.title: The House of mirth [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Terence Davies, Olivia Stewart and Three Rivers
results.brief_description: A detailed, passionate adaptation of Edith Wharton’s 1905 novel, “The House of Mirth” is Terence Davies’ finest film to date. Lily Bart (in an exquisite performance by “X-Files” star Gillian Anderson) is an intelligent, unconventional woman in her late 20s, torn between a constraining, rigid society and her own individuality. In order to remain a member of New York’s elite social circle, Lily realises she must marry a wealthy, respectable man. But finding someone who will nourish her intellect, appreciate her unconventionality and provide the funds is painstakingly difficult. The film’s most powerful scenes are those between Lily and the man she is evidently most attracted to, Lawrence Selden, who ironically is not wealthy enough to make him a suitable husband. With no job and dependent on her rich maiden aunt for a daily allowance, from whom she hopes to receive an inheritance, Lily mistakenly asks Gus Trenor for some assistance. This act of borrowing only leads to further complications, involving the cunning Mr. Rosedale, that entangle Lily and limit her options. “The House of Mirth” charts Lily’s progressive defeat and the suffering she endures as she loses her name and, concomitantly, social respect. Alone and ostracised, Lily’s finale is a monumental passage in the film. “The House of Mirth” is a tragic tale about a woman who tries desperately to both be true to her heart and play by society’s rules. But she can’t have both and ultimately ends up with nothing at all. New York upper class society is a character unto itself throughout his film - a conservative and rigid set of attitudes, sentiments, and values that have the power to do terrible evil. Stars Gillian Anderson, Dan Aykroyd, Anthony LaPaglia, Eric Stoltz, Eleanor Bron, Laura Linney.

results.title: Heaven's burning
results.creator_credit: Craig Lahiff, Al Clark, Helen Leake and Dup Art
results.brief_description: Midori (Yuki Kudoh) is a young Japanese bride, who, despising her new husband, decides to flee him on their wedding night. Faking her own kidnapping, and stranded in Sydney, Midori is then the victim of a real kidnap attempt during a violent bank robbery. Shw ends up on the road with the handsome getaway driver Colin (Russell Crowe), who saves her from execution at the hands of his cohorts, betraying them in the process. Pursued by the police, Midori’s enraged husband and Colin’s murderous gang, Colin and Midori flee towards the outback. En route the pair meet a slew of eccentric characters, attend a B and S ball and have a variety of experiences, which unites them romantically. “Heaven’s burning” is a road movie, and typically of the Australian genre, has the action contained within a deterministically peculiar outback culture. Midori’s ethnicity serves as a conduit on which to channel a range of unoriginal Aussie stereotypes, as well as highlighting racism and cultural intolerance. The film is a mix of genres - romance, crime flick, thriller - and is slavish in its desire to appear offbeat and original. Cast also includes Kenji Isomura, Ray Barrett and Robert Mammone.

results.title: Fast, cheap & out of control = Fast cheap and out of control [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Errol Morris and Fourth Floor Pictures
results.brief_description: Fast, cheap & out of control is another ‘non-fiction’ film from acclaimed director Errol Morris. It continues his highly imaginative and inventive exploration into the relationship between the individual and society. Four men are interviewed in this documentary, and are identified more according to their extraordinary, eccentric obsessions then anything else. They include: a lion tamer (Dave Hoover), a topiary gardener (George Mendonca), a mole-rat specialist (Ray Mendez) and a robot scientist (Rodney Brooks). Once again, Morris succeeds in presenting us with well-chosen, highly articulate characters who, in a relaxed manner, discuss the origins of their passion and reflect on its importance today. Despite their eccentricities, Morris refrains from judging or mocking each character and instead is even-handed and respectful. As they discuss their obsession, each reflects on philosophical matters that range from evolution, the Other, survival to life and death. Morris reveals how these obsessions reflect not only their personalities and values but also elemental emotions and thoughts: fear and survival for the lion tamer; nature and its human manipulation for the topiary; the Other and the act of confronting something completely foreign for the mole-rat specialist; and the interface between machine and man, technology and life for the robot scientist. Morris interweaves early cinema footage with present-day material in a dreamlike, musical manner that emphasises the connections between each individual’s obsessions. Ultimately, what these individuals obsessions come to represent is less an eccentricity or weirdness and much more an act of attempting to come to a genuine understanding of the world, society and human life.

results.title: Way down east [DVD]
results.brief_description: A country girl is tricked into a fake marriage by a lecherous playboy. He deserts her when she becomes pregnant. After the death of the baby she seeks refuge in the house of a puritanical squire. The melodramatic cliche of the original play is transformed, suffused with the timelessness of myth by Griffith and the principal players. The extraordinary delicacy and intensity of Gish is well complemented by the playing of Barthelmess as the country boy. The final scenes of fragility against the elements in the blizzard and on the icefloe (filmed at some risk to Gish and Barthelmess) is a tour-de-force of staging, composition and editing. Based on the play by Lottie Blair Parker, William Brady and Joseph R. Grisner. Cast includes Lillian Gish, Richard Barthelmess and Lowell Sherman. With musical soundtrack recorded in 1928 by Louis Silvers. This version was fully restored by film historian David Shepard.

results.title: Halloween
results.creator_credit: John Carpenter, Debra Hill and Falcon Film
results.brief_description: John Carpenter’s much imitated “Halloween” defined the eighties stalk and slasher genre, spawning inferior copies like the “Friday the 13th” series (including six sequels of its own), and for a time making the star Jamie Lee Curtis into the premium “scream queen”. Later on the conventions of the genre were clevely re-invented for a nineties audience by director Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson in “Scream”, which plays direct homage to “Halloween”. John Carpenter opens his film with an unnerving point of view shot of the young psychotic Michael Myers brutally stabbing his teenage sister to death on Halloween night. Flash forward to Halloween fifteen years later and Michael has escaped the mental institution he had been locked up in. Meanwhile shy, virginal teacher Laurie Strode (Jamie Lee Curtis) and her girlfriends are preparing for Halloween, unaware of the menace that lurks in their quiet suburban community. Carpenter makes great use of the sparse, atmospheric music score (which he also composed), and uses to the maximum creepy effect the white mask Michael Myers wears throughout the film. “Halloween” also establishes the classic horror genre rule - if you’re a sexually active teenager, you die! Cast also includes Donald Pleasence, P.J. Soles, Tony Moran.

results.title: Nosferatu [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Frederick Murnau, Albin Grau, Enrico Dieckman and Prana-Film
results.brief_description: Hutter is a German real estate agent newly married and extremely excited about his latest transaction, selling a property to the reclusive Herr Orlok, who lives in remote Transylvania. Despite the warnings of the local peasants and the imploring of his wife, Hutter travels to Orlok’s castle where he begins to suspect that his client may not be of this world. Orlok travels by boat to Bremen where he prepares to realise the evil intentions he nurses for Hutter’s beautiful young wife. Although the plot is quite close to that of Bram Stoker’s Dracula, the emotional and intellectual emphases are different. The figure of Count Orlok resembling an animated corpse is far from Stoker’s well-groomed, demonic vampire and Nosferatu exhibits none of the shadow play of Caligari. Director Murnau showed how the fantastic film could gain from the use of real settings and the imaginative treatment of space. This feeling of landscape became a central element of the classic vampire film.

results.title: The Magnificent rebel
results.creator_credit: Georg Tressler and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: A journey into Ludwig van Beethoven’s incredible life of music starring Carl Boehm, an Austrian actor-classical pianist, as Beethoven. The story begins in 1792 in Vienna where Beethoven, aged 22, is studying music and composition under one of the music masters of the time, Joseph Haydn. It is Beethoven’s early period when his enthusiasm is ahead of his ability, particularly in the high classical style, but it is also a time for him to establish himself as a pianist and a composer and earn an income. Beethoven struggled for many years to be accepted by the music discerning public and it was not until he composed his dramatic and tumultuous Symphony No. 5 that he eventually was widely acclaimed by his audience and became recognised on an international level. Now begins his middle period (around 1809 onwards), a time of prolific creativity and writing of symphonies, piano concertos and chamber music. However Beethoven also discovers that he has a hearing disorder that will eventually lead to profound deafness. So follows a period of torment, self-isolation and despair until an encounter and subsequent friendship with a young blind boy awakens Beethoven’s creative spirit to lead him into the late period of his musical career, a calmer and more mature period. The film climaxes with the “piece de resistance”, Beethoven’s Symphony No. 9. Cast also includes Giulia Rubini and Ivan Desny.

results.title: Lady of burlesque
results.creator_credit: William Wellman, Hunt Stromberg and Hunt Stromberg Productions
results.brief_description: Set in the late 1930s, this backstage mystery-comedy stars Barbara Stanwyck as Dixie Daisy, a burlesque artist who also arbitrates frequent disagreements between the chorus girls. When two girls are strangled with a G-string, the police point the finger at various crew members including Daisy and Biff (Michael O’Shea), a comic with designs on Daisy. Stanwyck plays Daisy as a tough-as-nails no-nonsense broad with enough chutzpah to carry the show, whose dialogue at times has a Howard Hawks-esque quality. This is a well-mounted independent production by a veteran ex-Metro producer with an authentic backstage atmosphere and directed at a fast pace by Wellman. Stanwyck sings “Take it off the E-string, Play it on the G-string” while dancing a ‘strip’ number. Also features: J. Edward Bromberg, Charles Dingle, and Frank Conroy. The film attracted an Oscar nomination for music score and Edith Head designed the costumes worn by Barbara Stanwyck. Based on a novel by the famed striptease artist Gypsy Rose Lee.

results.title: Happy go lovely
results.creator_credit: Bruce Humberstone, Marcel Hellman and Associated British Picture Corporation
results.brief_description: This Anglo-American musical/comedy “Happy go lovely” is set in Edinburgh, Scotland, during the Edinburgh festival. A desperate theatre director is staving off creditors and his production hangs in the balance when his leading star quits. None of his crew have been paid properly and are demanding remuneration. Janet Jones (Vera Ellen) is a chorus girl mistaken for the fiancee of local multi-millionaire B.G. Bruno. As a result she is promoted to leading lady and showered in gifts from local dress stores. Rumours drift back to Bruno about Miss Jones and when he calls on her she mistakes him for a reporter, Charlie. As Charlie/Bruno woos Janet complications ensue in a classic case of mistaken identity. The film features numerous song and dance sequences, many of which are in the style of ballet.
